Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Individual and Group Animal Flight Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Progress in understanding the individual and group maneuvers of flying animals has been slow to date, hampered by technical limitations in quantifying flight behavior and performance in the field. However, the diversity of form and function apparent in living bird, bat and insect species is related to the ability to maneuver, particularly to avoid or enable prey capture and prevail in contests with others of the same species - activities which cannot be adequately replicated in a laboratory. This research will take advantage of recent advances in low power, high-resolution, high-speed video technology to develop flexible recording techniques suitable for precisely measuring individual and group animal flight maneuvers in natural environments over a wide range of sizes and time scales. These capabilities will be used to address hypotheses on the fundamental relationships between shape, biomechanics and maneuverability in flying animals and on their group behavior. Similarities in basic grouping parameters will be examined among different bird or bat species known for varying degrees of coordinated behavior. In addition to providing insight into the biology of a range of animal species, discoveries in this area will also help speed development of micro-air vehicles, animal scale flying machines. Finally, this proposal will lead to rich, freely available data sets and ready-to-use software for other researchers.

As part of the education and outreach activities funded by this proposal, a partnership with UNC's Morehead Planetarium and Science Center will incorporate findings from this research and other recent studies of animal flight behavior and performance into a fulldome planetarium show and associated educational materials to be viewed by visiting North Carolina primary school students. The show and materials will also be shared with other planetariums worldwide.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project set out to use newly developed field videography recording methods to quantify the 3D flight trajectories, flight dynamics and group interactions of birds and other flying animals in their natural environment. The result of these efforts were a series of new datasets that reveal some of how flying animals use their capabilities, often producing new insight into topics that were previously studied in laboratory experiments. For example, birds chasing one another were found to maintain a high flapping frequency even at intermediate flight speeds where fast flapping is inefficient. However, fast flapping also maximizes the birds agility, likely a more important consideration during bird-bird chases.

The techniques used to measure the flight of individual birds also scale up to flocks, and we used them to quantify the dynamics of two different flocks: Chimney Swift migration roosting flocks, where hundreds to thousands of individual birds meet up and form a flock at dusk which circles and eventually enters a chimney for the night. We found that despite the cooperative nature of the overall flocking event and its dense appareance from the ground, birds in the flock are widely spaced, typically with a minimum bird-bird distance of 4 wingspans, and also do not cooperate when entering the chimney, even though they achieve entry rates of 5 or more birds per second.

We also recorded a different flocking system - 4 species of shorebirds in flocks of hundreds to approximately 1000 individuals recorded at migration stopovers. These species cover a 7-fold range of body mass, but unlike the swifts where birds essentially avoid each other in the air, we found that the shorebirds form a small-scale pattern within their large scale flocks, lining up tip-to-tip and recreating the nearest-neighbor pattern of a Canada Goose V-formation within their large-scale flock.  This tip-to-tip pattern was present in all four species and even in mixed-species flocks. Thus, it appears plausible that like the geese, the shorebirds are taking advantage of aerodynamic interactions to subsidize their flight cost.

Flight subsidies via environmental interactions, either with the physical environment such as gusts, thermals and wind shear, or the vortices created by other animals is one of the common themes in our findings from the many different components of this project. Thus, one of the ways that birds achieve vastly superior aerial endurance compared to micro air vehicles or drones of similar size is likely through use of environmental energy to reduce flight costs. Following up on these findings, future work in my research group includes laboratory study of the energetic and aerodynamic consequences of beneficial flow interactions using an animal flight wind tunnel.
